title: 113_hr1582
content: The "Energy Consumers Relief Act of 2013" prohibits the Environmental Protection Agency from finalizing energy-related rules costing over $1 billion if they will have significant adverse effects on the economy. The Secretary of Energy must determine the rule's impact before it can be promulgated. Before finalizing any energy-related rule costing over $1 billion, the EPA must report to Congress with details on the rule, its costs, benefits, and data reliability. Before finalizing any energy-related rule costing over $1 billion, the EPA must report to Congress with details on the rule, its costs, benefits, and data reliability. The report must include calculations, assumptions, limitations, certification of data preservation, availability for public review, estimates of energy price increases, and a description of employment effects. The Secretary of Energy, in consultation with relevant agencies, will conduct an analysis to determine the potential impacts of a rule on energy prices for consumers, fuel diversity, electric reliability, and energy supply. The Secretary of Energy, in consultation with other agencies, will analyze the potential impacts of a rule on energy prices, fuel diversity, electric reliability, and energy supply, including effects on low-income households, small businesses, and manufacturers. If adverse effects are determined, further consultations will be conducted to assess impacts on the economy. The Secretary, in consultation with other agencies, will analyze the economic impacts of a rule, considering costs, benefits, and effects on economic indicators. Results will be published in the Federal Register. SEC. 4. DEFINITIONS. This section defines terms like "direct costs" and "indirect costs" according to EPA guidelines. SEC. 5. PROHIBITION ON USE OF SOCIAL COST OF CARBON IN ANALYSIS. This section prohibits the use of social cost of carbon in rule analysis. SEC. 5. PROHIBITION ON USE OF SOCIAL COST OF CARBON IN ANALYSIS. The Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency is prohibited from using the social cost of carbon in cost-benefit analysis for energy-related rules costing over $1 billion without specific authorization from Federal law. The social cost of carbon refers to the monetized damages from increased carbon dioxide emissions. The House of Representatives passed a bill on August 1, 2013, related to monetized damages from increased carbon dioxide emissions.
